Award.AwardTitle: Characterizing the Evolutionary Behavior of Bacteria in the Presence of Iron Nanoparticles.

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Graves
1602593

The spread of multidrug resistant bacteria is now a crucial concern for modern society. For example in 2012, methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) killed more people in the USA than AIDS, hepatitis B, and tuberculosis combined. To address this concern there is a need for novel antimicrobial treatments. One of the most promising of these is the use of metallic/metallic oxide nanoparticles. However, many researchers in this field have not considered the possibility that bacteria can evolve resistance to metals and metallic oxides (silver, copper, iron) as quickly as they did to traditional antibiotics. This research project will specifically study the methodology, speed, and mechanism by which bacterium can evolve resistance to iron/iron oxide nanoparticles. To examine how resistance to iron toxicity may arise in bacteria, the PI proposes to utilize a series of laboratory experiments with genomic resequencing. This knowledge will provide science-based data for more appropriate use of these antimicrobials so that the development of resistance is avoided or minimized.

To examine how bacteria may evolve resistance to iron/iron oxide nanoparticles the PI will use laboratory experiments to produce iron resistant strains of E. coli K-12 MG1655 via exposure to ?Ã—-Fe2O3 (maghemite) and Fe3O4 (magnetite) nanoparticles. The PI will utilize different ancestral strains to derive into the two different types of iron resistant populations. One of the ancestors will have no prior metal resistance and the second ancestor will have a history of silver resistance. The PI will use whole genome resequencing to examine the genomes of the ancestors and the iron-resistant derived populations. This will allow the PI to test whether previously existing heavy metal resistance mechanisms provide an advantage in the development of resistance to magnetic iron oxide. These experiments will also allow the PI to test whether the genomic adaptations to ferrous iron (Fe2+) are different from those adaptations engendered by ferric iron (Fe3+) toxicity.

This project will provide crucial genomic-based information concerning the mechanisms by which bacteria evolve resistance to metal/metallic oxide nanoparticles. The resulting data will be useful for researchers developing nano-based interventions to control multi-drug resistant bacteria. The ability to control the development of resistance will improve the sustainability of potential medical uses of metallic/metallic oxide nanoparticles. This research could benefit both the scientific community in general by elucidating mechanisms of bacteria resistance and the general public by the reduction in infectious disease. This research will be conducted at the Joint School of Nanosciences and Nanoengineering through a partnership between North Carolina A &T State University (HBCU) and the University of North Carolina (UNC) Greensboro (a minority-serving institution). This project will also involve encouraging and mentoring underrepresented and first-generation college students in science and engineering disciplines

POR.DRECONTENT:
Iron nanoparticles have been proposed as a means to control multidrug resistant bacteria.  However, the only way that such schemes could work is if bacteria don't have the capacity to evolve resistance to iron nanoparticles.  To test if this was true, we used experimental evolution to produce strains of E. coli K-12 MG1655 that were resistant to excess amounts of iron Fe3O4 (magnetite) nanoparticles.  Two strains will be used to derive iron resistant populations, non-silver resistant and silver resistant.  This will allow us to test whether previously existing heavy metal resistance mechanisms provided an advantage in the capaciy of the bacteria to become resistance to excess magnetic iron oxide.

We then determined the capaciy of the evolved bacterial strains and controls to grow in the presence of increasing concentrations of iron oxide nanoparticles.  That allowed us to evaluate the limits of de novo evolution of iron oxide compounds under laboratory conditions. This also allowed us to determine if trade-offs existed with other resistances, such as those to traditional antibiotics or other metals such as silver.

We also determined if iron oxide resistance provides general metal resistance or is it specific to ferrous or ferric iron. 

Finally we employed whole genome resequencing to identify the genomic changes there were responsible for iron nanoparticle resistance. Specifically we wanted to know if new variants associated with iron resistance could include those that provide improved protection against oxidative stress damage.

The resuts of our study showed:

1. E. coli could readily evolve resistance to magnetite nanoparticles (FeNP). within 35--50 days.

2. That FeNP resistance also confers general metal resistance (ionic iron [II], ionic [III], gallium [III], and silver [i]. 

3. That FeNP resistance also confered resistance to antibiotics (ampicillin, chloramphenicol, polymixin-B, rifampicin, sulfanilamide, and tetracycline).

4. That the genetic changes required to get these resistances was simple (~17 genes for Fe2, 5 for Fe3, and 6 for FeNP). In genomic terms, who is at the party, the suspects in the crime.

5. That genetic changes were also associated with the FeNP also changed the patterns of gene expression. In genomic terms, what that person is doing at the party, the persons responsible for the crime.

6. That genetic background can, but does not always influence how evolution of FeNP resistance proceeds.

The take home message of this study is that metallic nanopartticles are not "magic bullets" to control multidrug resistant bacteria.  Not only are they not magic bullets, if used without foresight they coud lead to even worse bacterial varieties.

Broader Impacts

We were careful to desseminate these results to the professional communities that needed to know this information.  Specificallly we published an important review article in a leading materials sciene journal. The lead PI of this project is authoring a book with a major scientific publisher to teach the significance of these results to materials science, chemistry, and other professionals who are not familiar with the principles of microbial evolution.

Human Resources

This research was conducted at a HBCU, with over 97% enrollment of African American undergraduates.  This results of this work was included in undergraduate classes, and undergrad and graduate students participated in this result. These students received training in cutting edge methods of microbiology, genomics, evolution, DNA sequencing, gene expression profiling, and computatinal science.  Students earned PhDs, MS degrees, and BS degrees while working on this project.  Many of the undergraduates are applying to graduate PhD programs in one or more of the disciplnes listed above.
